div.p: ANTONIO: Okay, so let's say we've been using alcohol or drugs as a way to have fun for a while. It might be hard to imagine having a good time without them.
ANTONIO: But eventually, our brains will change back to a more normal state and we'll be able to find pleasure in life without high-risk choices.

ERIC: When I stopped drinking I was really concerned with a couple things, first the I would be bored a lot and secondly that I would have to stop doing all the things I liked doing that I enjoyed and having fun.

ERIC: But really in reality being in recovery hasn't stopped me from doing any of the things I really enjoy doing. I found that you know there are a lot of things actually missing out on because I built my life around drinking.
ERIC: I can now go out to concerts and actually enjoy them and listen to music. I can go out and enjoy dinner with friends. I can go to movies.
ERIC: I'm furtunate to live in a place where I can just be outside and there is a lot to do. I read more. I am more active physically, cause I feel better. I just feel physically a lot better.

ERIC: And you know not drinking has really enabled me to feel closer to people so the relationships that I do have are a lot more meaningful and enjoyable than they were before when a lot of them were built around me drinking.
ROB: Well I surrounded myself with people that drank and behaved like I did, because that's where I was comfortable.
ROB: And when I decided that it was time for me to make a change, a major change in my life, I couldn't hang out with people that drank and behaved the same way that I did.

ROB: It was foreign to me as a sober person, watching the behavior. I was like, "Wow, I behaved like that, that was disturbing." And those people didn't wanna hang out with me when I stopped drinking.
ROB: So it became pretty easy to detach from the old friends that I used to hang out with. For a while, about 6 months, it was a pretty bleak existence.
ROB: I did a lot of time reading, I spent a lot of time in my room. And I was comfortable doing that, I didn't feel lonely doing that, I kind of felt raw, a little fragile if you will.

ROB: And then when I decided it was time for me to be around people again, I went and found new friends. I started doing stuff that was kinda outside of my comfort zone, but stuff that I wanted to do.
ROB: I started playing in a band with a bunch of local kids in Scotland, where I was stationed, and that just opened a whole new community of people to hang out with.
ANTONIO: These people found fun and excitement in all different places, but they have one thing in common; they were all able to reclaim fun in their lives without returning to high-risk choices.
ANTONIO: Now I want to give you the opportunity to think of ways that you can do the same.
